Tel.: +81 11 706 6304; fax: +81 11 706 6304. Graphical abstract An iron(III)-phthalocyaninetetrasulfate (FePcTS) was axially coordinated to a series of imidazole functionalized silica, 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropylsilica (IPS) particles. Among the prepared FePcTS/IPS catalysts, catalytic activity for the oxidation of tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) for the smallest sized particle (<30μm) was more effective than larger sizes (145μm< and 45–145μm). The catalytic activity of FePcTS/IPS was compared with that of a structural analogue, iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin (FeTPPS) supported IPS (FeTPPS/IPS). The TOF values for the oxidation of TBBPA by FePcTS/IPS (11–17h−1) were much larger than the corresponding values for FeTPPS/IPS (0.7–3.5h−1) in the absence and presence of humic acid, a major coexistent substance in landfill leachates. To investigate the reasons for the differences in catalytic activities between the FePcTS and FeTPPS systems, the influence of ethanol, a SO4 − scavenger, on the oxidation of TBBPA oxidation was tested. The TOF values for FePcTS/IPS decreased with increasing ethanol concentration, while the catalytic activities for FeTPPS/IPS were not affected by adding ethanol. These results suggest that the higher catalytic activity of the FePcTS catalytic system can be attributed to the contribution of radical species, which can be generated via the homolysis of OO bonding in the Fe(III)-peroxo species. Keywords Iron(III)-phthalocyanine-4,4′,4″,4‴-tetrasulfonic acid Imidazole functionalized silica Iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin Catalytic oxidation 1 Introduction Water-soluble iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin (FeTPPS) have been shown to serve as a biomimetic model for the catalytic center of ligninolytic peroxidases, such as ligninases [1]. Halogenated phenols are oxidized by water-soluble iron(III)-porphyrins by H2O2 or KHSO5 as oxygen donors [2–12], and such catalytic systems can be used in the remediation of soils that are contaminated with organic pollutants [13–15]. On the other hand, an iron(III)-phthalocyanine-4,4′,4″,4‴-tetrasulfonic acid (FePcTS), a structural analogue of FeTPPS, also functions as a catalysis for the degradation of organic pollutants [16–20]. However, FeTPPS and FePcTS catalysts are both deactivated as a result of rapid self-degradation under highly oxidative conditions and by dimerization via the formation of μ-oxo iron(III) species [6,17,21]. The immobilization of iron(III)-porphyrin catalysts on solid supports has been employed to increase their stability towards oxidative self-degradation and to prevent catalyst deactivation caused by dimerization [22–28]. Among the supported catalysts, the immobilization of metalloporphyrins on silica surfaces via the axial coordination of the metal center to imidazole and pyridine ligands is one possible approach for mimicking naturally occurring ligninolytic peroxidases [29–34]. In particular, a FeTPPS catalyst supported on 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropylsilica (FeTPPS/IPS) was reported to be effective in the oxidative degradation of tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA), an endocrine disruptor that is found in landfill leachates [29]. It has been reported that the catalytic activities of FePcTS for the oxidation of chlorophenols and TBBPA are significantly higher than the corresponding values for FeTPPS [11,19,20]. However, the oxidative degradation of halogenated phenols using silica supported catalysts via the axial coordination of metallophthalocyanine to the imidazole ligand has not been examined in detail. In the present study, a FePcTS catalyst was supported on the various sized 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropylsilica (IPS) particles, and the catalytic activities for the oxidative degradation of TBBPA were compared as a function of particle size of the prepared FePcTS/IPS catalysts. If the catalyst were to be applied to the remediation of contaminated water such as landfill leachates, the influences of coexistence substances on the catalytic oxidation of TBBPA needs to be evaluated. Thus, catalytic activities of the various FePcTS/IPS catalysts in the presence of humic acid (HA), a major coexistent substance in leachates [35], was compared with the corresponding values for the FeTPPS/IPS catalyst. In addition, differences in the reaction mechanisms between FePcTS and FeTPPS were discussed, based on the formation of radical species in ESR spectra. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The FePcTS catalyst was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich (Buchs, SG, Switzerland), and the FeTPPS catalyst was synthesized according to a method, described in a previous report [36]. The (3-isocyanatopropyl)triethoxysilane and N-(3-aminopropyl)imidazole were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry (Tokyo, Japan). KHSO5 was obtained as a triple salt, 2KHSO5·KHSO4·K2SO4 (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany). TBBPA (98% purity) was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry, and a stock solution (0.01M) was prepared by dissolving it in acetonitrile. 1,4-Dioxane, acetonitrile, methanol, 2-propanol (HPLC grade) and n-hexane (dioxin grade) were purchased from Wako Pure Chemicals (Osaka, Japan) and were used without further purification. 5,5-Dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO), a spin trapping reagent, was purchased from Labotec (Hiroshima, Japan). Powdered silica gel samples (10–40 mesh, 35–70 mesh and 230 mesh<) were purchased from Nacalai Tesque Inc (Kyoto, Japan). These powders were passed through stainless steel sieves of 145μm, 45μm and 30μm, and the particles with diameters above 145μm, 45–145μm and below 30μm were collected and used in the tests. The HA sample used in the present study was extracted from a Shinshinotsu peat soil (Hokkaido, Japan) and purified according to a previously reported method [37]. 2.2 Synthesis of FePcTS/IPS and FeTPPS/IPS catalysts Scheme 1 shows the synthesis of the FePcTS/IPS catalyst, which was based on a previously reported method for preparing FeTPPS/IPS catalyst [29]. Briefly, 1.3mL of (3-isocyanatopropyl)triethoxysilane and 700μL of N-(3-aminopropyl)imidazole were added to 20mL of 1,4-dioxiane in a 200mL 3-neck flask with stirring. The resulting mixture was then stirred for 12h at 70°C to produce 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropylsilane. Subsequently, 1.5g of silica gel was added, and the mixture was further stirred at 80°C for 12h to produce the IPS. The resulting solid was separated by centrifugation (10,000rpm, 15min). The prepared IPS was consecutively washed with 0.5M HCl, H2O, 0.1M NaOH and finally washed with ultra-pure water. The powdered IPS was then obtained by freeze-drying. In a 50mL Erlenmeyer flask, 0.5g of IPS was added to 15mL of aqueous solutions of FePcTS or FeTPPS (10mM). The mixture was shaken at 25°C and 150rpm for 24h in the dark. After the reaction, the FePcTS or FeTPPS/IPS was collected by the filtration and washed 4 times with 1M NaCl aqueous, ultra-pure water, and the powdered sample was then obtained by freeze-drying. 2.3 Analyses of the prepared catalysts The iron content of the prepared catalysts (μmolg−1) corresponded to the amounts of Fe loaded in the FePcTS and FeTPPS catalysts. Thus, the iron contents were determined by ICP-AES after the wet-digestion of the solid catalysts with a mixture of HF, HNO3 and HCl (1:1:3, v/v/v), as described in a previous report [38]. FT-IR spectra of the silica gel (SiO2), the IPS and the FePcTS/IPS catalyst (small size, <30μm) were collected using an FT/IR 600-type spectrophotometer (Japan Spectroscopic Co., Ltd., Hachioji, Tokyo, Japan). Spectra were recorded between 4000 and 400cm−1 at a resolution of 4cm−1, using a KBr disk. The zeta potentials of SiO2 and FePcTS/IPS (<30μm) were recorded on an ELSZ-1000 type zeta-potential & particle size analyzer (Otsuka Electronics, Osaka, Japan). 2.4 Assay for catalytic activity A 20mL aliquot of a 0.02M Na2HPO4/NaH2PO4 buffer containing 50μM TBBPA, 0–50mgL−1 HA and 5μM FePcTS/IPS at pH 8 was placed in a 50mL Erlenmeyer flask. Subsequently, 25μL of an aqueous 0.1M KHSO5 solution was added, and the flask was then subjected to shaking for 180rpm at 25°C in an incubator. After an arbitrary reaction period, a 0.8mL aliquot of the reaction mixture was withdrawn and 0.4mL of 2-propanol was then added. After centrifugation (6600rpm, 5min), a 20μL aliquot of the supernatant was injected into a PU-980 type HPLC pumping system (Japan Spectroscopic Co., Ltd.). The mobile phase consisted of a mixture of 0.08% aqueous H3PO4 and methanol (20/80, v/v), and the flow rate was set at 1mLmin−1. A 5C18-MS Cosmosil packed column (4.6mm i.d.×250mm, Nacalai Tesque Inc.) was used as the solid phase, and the column temperature was maintained at 50°C. The UV absorption of TBBPA was measured at the detection wavelength of 220nm. Bromide ions in the supernatant were analyzed by ion chromatography (IC-20 type, Thermo Scientific, Sunnyvale, CA, USA). 2.5 Analyses of oxidation products After filtration of the reaction mixtures at the incubation periods of 10, 30, 60 and 120min, 1mL of 1M ascorbic acid was added to the filtrate, and the pH of the solution was adjusted to 11–11.5 by adding aqueous K2CO3 (600gL−1). Subsequently, 5mL of acetic anhydride was added dropwise to the solution, and 0.5mL of a 1mM anthracene solution in hexane/acetone mixture (1/1, v/v) was added as an internal standard (ISTD) for the GC/MS analysis. This mixture was extracted twice with 15mL portions of n-hexane, and the combined extracts were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. After filtration, the extract was evaporated under a stream of dry N2, and the residue was dissolved in 0.25mL of n-hexane. A 1μL aliquot of the extract was introduced into the GC-17A/QP5050 GC/MS system (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan). A Quadrex methyl silicon capillary column (0.25mm i.d.×25m) was employed in the separation. The temperature program was as follows: 65°C for 1.5min, 65–120°C at 35°Cmin−1, 120–300°C at 4°Cmin−1 and a 300°C hold for 10min. A standard sample of 4-(2-hydoroxyisopropyl)-2,6-dibromophenol (2HIP-26DBP) was synthesized, based on a previous report [11]. 2.6 ESR spectra FePcTS and FeTPPS (100μM) or FePcTS/IPS (5μM) were dissolved or suspended in 0.2M phosphate buffer at pH 6, which contained 0.9M DMPO under a N2 atmosphere. After adding KHSO5 (1mM), ESR spectra were recorded. The spectra were recorded at room temperature using a quartz flat cell on a JES-TE300 ESR Spectrometer (JEOL, Akishima, Tokyo, Japan) under the following conditions: microwave power 20mW; microwave frequency 9.42GHz; magnetic field 335.000mT; field amplitude ±4.000mT; modulation amplitude 0.079mT; modulation width 20μT; sweep time 2min; and the time constant was 0.03s. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the prepared FePcTS/IPS catalysts Fig. 1 shows FT-IR spectra for SiO2, IPS and small sized FePcTS/IPS (<30μm). The spectrum of SiO2 showed characteristic bands for OH stretching (3430cm−1) and asymmetrical SiOSi stretching vibration (1050–1190cm−1). For the IPS, the characteristic bands for symmetrical and asymmetrical CH vibration (2800–3000cm−1) and CC, CN ring stretching vibration (1411, 1509, 1567 and 1635cm−1) from the imidazole moiety also appeared, verifying the incorporation of 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropyl group into SiO2. In the spectrum of FePcTS/IPS, peaks corresponding to the 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropyl group were weakened, and the peaks at 1507 and 1411cm−1 (arrows in Fig. 1) were largely decreased, being consistent with the coordination with Fe in the FePcTS. Change in the surface chemistry of the catalyst was characterized by a zeta potential analysis, which is related to the surface charge (Fig. 2 ). The point of zero charge for the unmodified SiO2 and FePcTS/IPS catalyst were estimated to be 3.91 and 4.57, respectively. In the FePcTS catalyst, the positive charges below the point of zero charge (i.e., pH 4.57) are due to the protonation of unmodified imidazole groups. These results show that the catalyst surfaces are negatively charged in a solution at pH 8, which was used in the catalytic activity test. 3.2 Influence of particle size for FePcTS/IPS on the catalytic activity Fig. 3 shows the kinetics of monopersulfate oxidation of TBBPA for various sizes of FePcTS/IPS catalysts. In the presence of KHSO5 alone (○ in Fig. 3), approximately 25% of the TBBPA was degraded after an 8h period, while no debromination was observed. This indicates that KHSO5 alone has oxidizing capability to TBBPA. However, the rates of TBBPA degradation increased significantly in the presence of the FePcTS/IPS catalysts (■, ● and ▲ in Fig. 3), compared to that in the presence of KHSO5 alone. As summarized in Table 1 , the pseudo-first-order rate constants (k obs) for the large (145μm<, L), middle (45–145μm,M) and small (<30μm, S) sized FePcTS/IPS catalysts were estimated from the kinetic curves, and turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by dividing the initial degradation rate (μMh−1) by the catalyst concentration (μM) that was calculated from the iron content in the catalyst. The k obs and TOF values for the small sized FePcTS/IPS were the largest of the three catalysts. The amount of FePcTS loaded in the L-size FePcTS/IPS was larger than the values for the middle and small sized catalysts. If the catalyst concentration would be fixed, the catalytic activity might be the same for different particle size. In the case of a homogeneous FePcTS/KHSO5 catalytic system [17,19], the substrate was found to be degraded rapidly, because the probability of contact between catalyst particles and substrate molecules is very high. Thus, the higher TOF value for the small sized catalyst can be attributed to the higher reaction rate due to the higher probability of contact, as would be expected for a homogeneous catalyst. These results suggest that the particle size of the catalyst is one of the important factors in achieving a higher catalytic activity. Hereafter, the tests for TBBPA degradation were performed using the small sized FePcTS/IPS catalyst. Fig. 4 provides information regarding the reusability of the small sized catalyst. More than 90% TBBPA degradation was observed when the catalyst was reused 6 times, while the percent TBBPA degradation was decreased to 83% in the case of reuse the 7th time. The elution of iron into the aqueous phase of the reaction mixture, which was 20mL and contained 5μM FePcTS/IPS, 0.1mM KHSO5 and 50μM TBBPA at pH 8, for the 2h reaction period was checked using an atomic absorption spectrometry. The concentration of Fe in the reaction mixture was 0.46±0.08μM, which corresponded to a 9.3% loss of the iron that was loaded to the catalyst. 3.3 Influence of HA on the catalytic activity In the practical use of the catalysts, the influences of coexistent substances in the targeted sites on the catalytic activities should be investigated. If the FePcTS/IPS catalyst would be applied to the degradation of TBBPA in landfill leachates, HA would be regarded as a major coexistent substance, since it is frequently present at levels of several ten mgL−1. Fig. 5 shows kinetic curves for TBBPA degradation and debromination in the presence of 5–50mgL−1 HA. Debromination was substantially inhibited when HA was present at a level of 5mgL−1 (Fig. 5a), while the degradation of TBBPA was only slightly inhibited in the presence of 10mgL−1 HA. We previously reported on the inhibition of TBBPA degradation using a FeTPPS/IPS catalyst in the presence of HA [29]. HAs are naturally occurring dark-colored polymers, which contain a variety of phenolic acids in their structures [39,40]. Thus, the phenolic acids in HAs may also be oxidized by the FePcTS/KHSO5 catalytic system, and this would compete with the oxidation of TBBPA. The TOF values for TBBPA degradation by the FeTPPS/IPS catalyst were estimated, based on the kinetic curves obtained in this study, and these values were compared with those for the FePcTS/IPS catalyst (Table 2 ). Even in the absence and presence of HA, the TOF values for the FePcTS/IPS catalyst (10.5–16.8h−1) were much larger than those for the FeTPPS/IPS catalyst (0.71–3.52h−1). The TOFHA/TOFnone ratio in Table 2 indicates the degree of inhibition of TBBPA degradation by HA [41]. That is, the smaller the TOFHA value, the lower is the TOFHA/TOFnone ratio, indicating a significant inhibition in the presence of HA. As listed in Table 2, the TOFHA/TOFnone ratios for the FePcTS/IPS catalyst were clearly larger than those for the FeTPPS/IPS catalyst. These results show that the level of inhibition of the TBBPA degradation by HA is lower in the FePcTS/IPS catalyst, compared to the FeTPPS/IPS catalyst. 3.4 Oxidation products GC/MS chromatograms of hexane extracts from the reaction mixtures are shown in Fig. 6 a. The peak with a retention time of 18.10min increased up to a reaction period of 60min reaction period, and was assigned as the acetylated derivative of 2HIP-26DBP (Fig. 6b), based on its mass spectrum: m/z [relative intensity, fragment ions]; 352 [1.55, M+]; 310 [15.7, (MCH2CO)+]; 295 [42.8, (MC2H5CO)+]; 214 [1.39, (MC2H5COHBr)+]. The concentration of the 2HIP-26DBP acetylated derivative increased up to a 60min period and then decreased, as shown in Fig. 6b. It therefore appears that this product is further oxidized. However, the concentrations of total organic carbon in the reaction mixture were unchanged before and after the reaction, showing that TBBPA is not mineralized to CO2. Thus, 2HIP-26DBP can be converted to more hydroxylated compounds and/or polymerized compounds. However, no hydroxylated compounds were detected. In the case of a 60min reaction period, a small peak corresponding to a brominated compound was detected at the retention time of 52.14min (* in Fig. 6a), which was assigned as a coupling compound produced by a reaction between TBBPA and 2,6-dibromophenol (Fig. 6c) based on its mass spectrum: 836 [11.0, M+]; 794 [16.4, (MCH2CO)+]; 779 [7.52, (MC2H5CO)+]; 755 [1.54, (MHBr)+]; 512 [0.81, (M4HBr)+]; 293 [2.01, C6H9OBr2 +]. The trends for the oxidation products, detected in the FePcTS/IPS catalytic system, are quite similar to the previously reported results for homogeneous FePcTS and FeTPPS catalytic systems [11,20]. 3.5 Differences in reaction mechanisms between the FePcTS and FeTPPS systems 3.5.1 Influence of radical scavenger on catalytic activity As shown in Fig. 3, traces of TBBPA were degraded in the presence of 100μM KHSO5 alone. To compare the catalytic activity of FePcTS/IPS with that of FeTPPS/IPS without the degradation of TBBPA in the presence of KHSO5 alone, the lower concentration of KHSO5 (10μM) was employed. Fig. 7 shows the kinetic curves of TBBPA degradation for the FePcTS/IPS and FeTPPS/IPS catalysts at the lower concentrations of KHSO5 (10μM) and catalysts (1μM). The TOF value for FePcTS/IPS (31h−1) was larger than that for FeTPPS/IPS (17h−1), confirming that the catalytic activity of the FePcTS/IPS catalyst is higher than that of FeTPPS. Heme type complexes, such as FeTPPS, can form the Fe(III)-peroxo complex as a reaction intermediate [1]. When the oxygen donor is KHSO5, a Fe(III)OOSO3 complex can be formed as the Fe(III)-peroxo species. If the OO bonding in the Fe(III)-peroxo complex would be cleaved via homolysis, the Fe(III)OOSO3 − complex would be decomposed to a ferryl-oxo species (Fe(IV)O) and a sulfate radical (SO4 −). This type of radical is known to be a strong oxidant and can oxidize organic substrates [42,43]. In general, ethanol can rapidly react with SO4 − at the rate constant of (1.6–7.7)×109 M−1 s−1 [44], and serves as a scavenger of radical species. Thus, the catalytic activity for TBBPA degradation would be affected by adding ethanol, if such a radical species might participate in the reactions. Fig. 8 shows the influence of ethanol concentration on the TOF values for the FePcTS/IPS and FeTPPS/IPS catalysts. The TOF for the FePcTS/IPS catalyst decreased with increasing ethanol concentration, while TOF for the FeTPPS/IPS catalyst was not dependent on the ethanol concentration. These results suggest that radical species, such as SO4 −, can contribute to the oxidation of TBBPA in the case of the FePcTS/IPS catalytic system. 3.5.2 ESR spectra KHSO5 can be activated to generate HO and SO4 − in the presence of iron [42,45]. As described above, the degradation of TBBPA is affected by a radical scavenger for the case of FePcTS/IPS catalyst. To detect the reasonable radical species, a spin-trap ESR technique using DMPO was attempted for aqueous mixtures of FePcTS+KHSO5, FeTPPS+KHSO5 and FePcTS/IPS+KHSO5 (Fig. 9 ). The nine peaks in the ESR spectra with hyperfine splitting constants of A N =0.72mT and A H(2H)=0.42mT were observed, which are inconsistent with the values for the reported DMPO-SO4 adduct [45,46]. These peaks (● in Fig. 9) were assigned as DMPOX (5,5-dimethyl-2-oxo-pyrroline-1-oxyl), as reported previously [24,47]. It has been reported that the DMPO-SO4 adduct is difficult to detect because of its lower sensitivity and short life-time [48]. Thus, the DMPOX peak can be originated from the DMPO-SO4 adduct, as shown in Scheme 2 [47]. As shown in Fig. 9, small peaks for DMPOX were observed in the presence of KHSO5 alone. However, the intensities of the DMPOX peaks for the FePcTS and FePcTS/IPS catalysts were much higher than those for the FeTPPS catalyst. Fig. 10 a shows the decrease in the peak at g =2.003 of DMPOX after adding KHSO5. Although the DMPOX peaks in the FePcTS/IPS and FeTPPS catalytic systems remained for periods up to 40min, the DMPOX peak for the FePcTS catalyst disappeared after a reaction time of 25min. This suggests that DMPOX is further oxidized by the FePcTS/KHSO5 catalytic system. These results indicate that the levels of radical generation by the FePcTS and FePcTS/IPS catalysts are much higher than that for the FeTPPS catalyst. Fig. 10b shows the variations in ESR spectra in the presence of KHSO5 alone. After a 17min incubation period, the DMPOX peaks (Fig. 10b, ●) disappeared completely and new peaks with hyperfine splitting constant of A H(1H)=1.47mT and A H(2H)=1.47mT appeared, which was assigned to a DMPOOH adduct, as described in previous reports [43,45,46]. In the ESR spectra of the FeTPPS, FePcTS and FePcTS/IPC catalysts, no DMPOOH peaks were observed from 2.5 to 90min. The degradation of TBBPA in the absence of the FePcTS catalyst in Fig. 3 can be attributed to the generation of HO from KHSO5. The KHSO5 oxidation of TBBPA by FeTPPS and FePcTS probably proceeds via the peroxidase-shunt pathway, as shown in Scheme 3 [1]. In the case of π-electron conjugated systems, FePcTS has an electron-rich molecular environment, compared to FeTPPS. Such difference in electronic nature between FePcTS and FeTPPS can affect the cleavage of OO bond in the L-Fe(III)-peroxo species (L-Fe(III)OOSO3 −). According to findings reported by Nam et al. [49], an electron-deficient iron-porphyrin catalyst showed a tendency to cleave OO bond heterolytically, while an electron-rich catalyst cleaved OO bond homolytically. Thus, in the activation of KHSO5, the Fe(III) center of the porphyrin and phthalocyanine ligands (L) forms L-Fe(III)OOSO3 − via coordination with KHSO5, and the OO bonding is cleaved to produce L-Fe(IV)O and L + Fe(IV)O species via homolysis and heterolysis, respectively [49–51]. On the one hand, the homolysis and heterolysis of the OO bonding in the L-Fe(III)OOSO3 − species can generate SO4 − and HSO4 −, respectively. The results for the influence of a radical scavenger on catalytic activities for TBBPA oxidation (Fig. 8) and ESR spectra (Figs. 9 and 10) suggest that homolysis is dominant in the FePcTS catalytic system, and radical species that are generated via the homolysis of OO bonding for the L-Fe(III)-peroxo species contribute to the higher catalytic activity in the FePcTS catalytic system. 4 Conclusions The FePcTS was axially coordinated with a nitrogen atom in imidazole functionalized silica, IPS. The catalytic activity for TBBPA oxidation in presence of the FePcTS/IPS catalyst was significantly higher than that for the iron(III)-porphyrin supported IPS (FeTPPS/IPS) catalyst in the absence and presence of HA, which is a major coexistent substance in landfill leachates. The catalytic activity for TBBPA oxidation in the case of FePcTS decreased substantially with increasing ethanol concentration, the latter of which is known to be SO4 − scavenger. Although a DMPO-SO4 adduct could not be detected directly as an ESR signal, the larger peaks for DMPOX in the ESR spectra in the presence of FePcTS and FePcTS/IPS catalysts suggested that the homolysis of OO bonding in Fe(III)-peroxo species yield radical species, such as SO4 −. The participation of such radical species in the oxidation reaction contributes to the higher catalytic activity in the FePcTS and FePcTS/IPS catalytic systems. coredata.dc:description: An iron(III)-phthalocyaninetetrasulfate (FePcTS) was axially coordinated to a series of imidazole functionalized silica, 3-(1-imidazolyl)propylcarbamoyl-3′-aminopropylsilica (IPS) particles. Among the prepared FePcTS/IPS catalysts, catalytic activity for the oxidation of tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) for the smallest sized particle (<30μm) was more effective than larger sizes (145μm< and 45–145μm). The catalytic activity of FePcTS/IPS was compared with that of a structural analogue, iron(III)-tetrakis(p-sulfonatephenyl)porphyrin (FeTPPS) supported IPS (FeTPPS/IPS). The TOF values for the oxidation of TBBPA by FePcTS/IPS (11–17h−1) were much larger than the corresponding values for FeTPPS/IPS (0.7–3.5h−1) in the absence and presence of humic acid, a major coexistent substance in landfill leachates. To investigate the reasons for the differences in catalytic activities between the FePcTS and FeTPPS systems, the influence of ethanol, a SO4 − scavenger, on the oxidation of TBBPA oxidation was tested. The TOF values for FePcTS/IPS decreased with increasing ethanol concentration, while the catalytic activities for FeTPPS/IPS were not affected by adding ethanol. These results suggest that the higher catalytic activity of the FePcTS catalytic system can be attributed to the contribution of radical species, which can be generated via the homolysis of OO bonding in the Fe(III)-peroxo species.
coredata.dc:title: Monopersulfate oxidation of tetrabromobisphenol A by an iron(III)-phthalocyaninetetrasulfate catalyst coordinated to imidazole functionalized silica particles
